Title: The entorhinal cortex of the monkey: I. Cytoarchitectonic organization
Abstract:
As an essential preliminary to a series of experimental studies of the afferent and efferent connections of the monkey
entorhinal cortex, we have carried out a detailed analysis of its cytoarchitectonic organization. Primarily on the basis of
features observed in Nissl- and fiber-stained preparations, supplemented with Golgi-stained material and preparations stained for heavy metals by Timm's method and histochemically for acetylcholinesterase, the entorhinal cortex has been divided into seven fields that are named according to their rostrocaudal and mediolateral positions except for one rostrally located field
that is named for the prominent input that it receives from the olfactory bulb. At rostral levels, the entorhinal cortex is marked
by a number of morphological inhomogeneities. The neurons tend to be organized in patches that are surrounded by large,
thick, radially oriented bundles of fibers. At caudal levels, the entorhinal cortex has a more distinctly laminated appearance,
reminiscent of that in the neocortex, and most of the neurons and fiber fascicles are arranged in discrete radial columns. The
cortical region adjoining the entorhinal cortex laterally, which is commonly known as the "perirhinal cortex," is in fact
composed of two separate fields corresponding to areas 35 and 36 of Brodmann. Area 35 occupies the fundus and part of
the lateral aspect of the rhinal sulcus. Area 36 extends from the lateral bank of the rhinal sulcus into the inferior temporal
gyrus, where it borders fields TA and TE rostrally, and field TF of the parahippocampal gyrus caudally. The surface extents
of each of the entorhinal fields have been determined by making "unfolded" two-dimensional maps of the region and
measuring the areas with a computerized digitizing system.

@BrainMaps_Delineation.Citation:
" We have taken as our starting point the cytoarchitectonic
features emphasized by Van Hoesen and Pandya ('75) in their study of the rhesus monkey enthorhinal cortex (Fig. 4D)......However, when we attempted to apply these cytoarchitectonic criteria to these fascicularis monkey, we found that by themselves they were inadequate, in large part because there seems to be a number of subtle differences in the organization of the entorhinal in thetwo allopatric species. It is for this reason, rather than any fundamental disagreement with Van Hoesen and Pandya's ('75a) description, that we have departed from their account. Indeed, our own observations on the rhesus monkey entorhinal cortex tend to support their analysis and have brought to light a number of differences in the two species......The various subfields of the entorhinal cortex that we have identified in the fascicularis monkey are illustrated in Fig. 5, ...To indicate the relative areal extents of the various fields, an unfolded map of the entire entorhinal cortex, together with areas 35 and 36, is shown in Figure 10. " (p. 340, 342)
@BrainMaps_Delineation.Comments: Each subdivision of the entorhinal cortex is explicitly described textually.

@BrainMaps_Methods.MethodicalDetails: Timm's method (modified by Van der Loos, '56)

@InterMapRelations.Citation: "We have also analyzed the cytoarchitectonic fields that occupy the lateral bank of the rhinal sulcus. Taken together these fields are often called the perirhinal cortex. Brodmann ('09) initially identified two cortical fields within this region, areas 35 and 36. Van Hoesen and Pandya ('75) have also recognized two fields in this region but refer to them as areas 35a and 35b. In our judgement area 35 is quite distinct from area 36 and for this reason we have followed Brodmann's ('09) terminology." (p. 354)
@InterMapRelations.Comments:
Brodmann ('09) describes both areas 35 and 36 for the human brain, but only an area 35 for the monkey brain.
Because of that it would be wrong to say, that B09-36 is identical to AIC87-36, because he didn't describe area 36 for the monkey brain.

@InterMapRelations.Citation: "We have also analyzed the cytoarchitectonic fields that occupy the lateral bank of the rhinal sulcus. Taken together these fields are often called the perirhinal cortex. Brodmann ('09) initially identified two cortical fields within this region, areas 35 and 36. Van Hoesen and Pandya ('75) have also recognized two fields in this region but refer to them as areas 35a and 35b. In our judgement area 35 is quite distinct from area 36 and for this reason we have followed Brodmann's ('09) terminology." (p. 354)

"We have also analyzed the cytoarchitectonic fields that occupy the lateral bank of the rhinal sulcus. Taken together these fields are often called the perirhinal cortex. Brodmann ('09) initially identified two cortical fields within this region, areas 35 and 36. Van Hoesen and Pandya ('75) have also recognized two fields in this region but refer to them as areas 35a and 35b. In our judgement area 35 is quite distinct from area 36 and for this reason we have followed Brodmann's ('09) terminology." (p. 354)
"...We have referred to this area as the lateral entorhinal field (EL), and have further subdivided into rostral (ELr) and caudal (ELc) subdivisions." (p. 354)

"EO (the olfactory field of the entorhinal cortex) ... Topographically, EO is located at the rostral pole of the entorhinal cortex; here it adjoins the ventral part of the piriform cortex." (p. 342) " The only entorhinal field that is not named for its topographic position is the olfactory portion of the entorhinal cortex (EO)." (p. 354)
"ER (the rostral entorhinal cortex). Field ER is present only in the rostral third of the entorhinal cortex, where it is placed between eO and ELr." (p. 342)
"Because there appear to be significant differences in the morphology of this field along its rostrocaudal dimension, we have divided it into rostral (ELr) and caudal (ELc) divisions." (p. 342)
"Because there appear to be significant differences in the morphology of this field along its rostrocaudal dimension, we have divided it into rostral (ELr) and caudal (ELc) divisions." (p. 342)

"Most rostrally, it borders the piriform cortex, which it closely resembles; further caudally the entorhinal cortex adjoins the periamygdaloid cortex (area51), from which it is separated by a shallow groove (the sulcus semiannularis); ..." (p. 330)

"The term entorhinal area seems to have been introduced by Brodmann ('09) for the cortical field medial to the rhinal sulcus, which he designated area 28 and distinguished as a separated cytoarchitectonic zone from the more laterally located perirhinal cortex (his area 35) and the ectorhinal cortex (area 36)." (p. 326)

"In agreement with Van Hoesen and Pandya ('75), we have found that the entorhinal cortex along the medial bank of the rhinal sulcus is distinct from the more medial fields. However, ... , we have not followed them in designating this area " the prorhinal cortex ".Because there appear to be significant differences in the morphology of this field along its rostrocaudal dimension, we have divided it into rostral (ELr) and caudal (ELc) divisions." (p. 342) " The increase in cell density is particulary noticeable in ELc, where there is an evident increase in the number of small cells that fill in the gaps seen in ELr and ER. In our fiber preparations, there is a dense meshwork of in layer III that continues intolayers II and I. This is in contrast to the radially disposed bundles seen in ER and EI. A similar dense fiber plexus was reported by Van Hoesen and Pandya ('75) in thier region Pr2." (p. 344) " In agreement with Van Hoesen and Pandya ('75a) we have also recognized that the portion of the entorhinal cortex that borders the medial bank of the rhinal sulcus is distinct from the more medially situated fields. However, unlike Van Hoesen and Pandya ('75a), who identified this area as the 'prorhinal cortex' (and hence considered it to be quite separate from the rest of the entorhinal cortex), we consider it to be a subdivision of the entorhinal cortex since, as our experimental studies have shown, it project sto the dentate gyrus as do all other entorhinal fields.We have referred to this area as the lateral entorhinal field (EL), and have further subdivided into rostral (ELr) and caudal (ELc) subdivisions." (p. 354)

"In agreement with Van Hoesen and Pandya ('75), we have found that the entorhinal cortex along the medial bank of the rhinal sulcus is distinct from the more medial fields. However, ... , we have not followed them in designating this area " the prorhinal cortex ".Because there appear to be significant differences in the morphology of this field along its rostrocaudal dimension, we have divided it into rostral (ELr) and caudal (ELc) divisions." (p. 342) " The increase in cell density is particulary noticeable in ELc, where there is an evident increase in the number of small cells that fill in the gaps seen in ELr and ER. In our fiber preparations, there is a dense meshwork of in layer III that continues intolayers II and I. This is in contrast to the radially disposed bundles seen in ER and EI. A similar dense fiber plexus was reported by Van Hoesen and Pandya ('75) in thier region Pr2." (p. 344) " In agreement with Van Hoesen and Pandya ('75a) we have also recognized that the portion of the entorhinal cortex that borders the medial bank of the rhinal sulcus is distinct from the more medially situated fields. However, unlike Van Hoesen and Pandya ('75a), who identified this area as the 'prorhinal cortex' (and hence considered it to be quite separate from the rest of the entorhinal cortex), we consider it to be a subdivision of the entorhinal cortex since, as our experimental studies have shown, it project sto the dentate gyrus as do all other entorhinal fields.We have referred to this area as the lateral entorhinal field (EL), and have further subdivided into rostral (ELr) and caudal (ELc) subdivisions." (p. 354)

"In agreement with Van Hoesen and Pandya ('75), we have found that the entorhinal cortex along the medial bank of the rhinal sulcus is distinct from the more medial fields. However, ... , we have not followed them in designating this area " the prorhinal cortex ".Because there appear to be significant differences in the morphology of this field along its rostrocaudal dimension, we have divided it into rostral (ELr) and caudal (ELc) divisions." (p. 342) " The increase in cell density is particulary noticeable in ELc, where there is an evident increase in the number of small cells that fill in the gaps seen in ELr and ER. In our fiber preparations, there is a dense meshwork of in layer III that continues intolayers II and I. This is in contrast to the radially disposed bundles seen in ER and EI. A similar dense fiber plexus was reported by Van Hoesen and Pandya ('75) in thier region Pr2." (p. 344) " In agreement with Van Hoesen and Pandya ('75a) we have also recognized that the portion of the entorhinal cortex that borders the medial bank of the rhinal sulcus is distinct from the more medially situated fields. However, unlike Van Hoesen and Pandya ('75a), who identified this area as the 'prorhinal cortex' (and hence considered it to be quite separate from the rest of the entorhinal cortex), we consider it to be a subdivision of the entorhinal cortex since, as our experimental studies have shown, it project sto the dentate gyrus as do all other entorhinal fields.We have referred to this area as the lateral entorhinal field (EL), and have further subdivided into rostral (ELr) and caudal (ELc) subdivisions." (p. 354)

@InterMapRelations.Comments: Area PAC (periamygdaloid cortex) seems to be identical in both papers, because  they have a common author (D.G.Amaral)and approximately the same location.
Area S ( subiculum) seems to be identical in both papers, because (i) they have a common author (D.G.Amaral) and (ii) both areas have the same abbreviation.
Area PaS (Parasubiculum) seems to be identical in both papers, because (i) they have a common author (D.G.Amaral) and (ii) both areas have the same abbreviation.

@InterMapRelations.Citation: "Layer II in the caudal part of area 36 (36c) has the same bilaminate appearance as the rostral part of the field (36r) but has a more uniform appearance and lacks the dense population of satellite glia." (p. 349)

"Layer II in the caudal part of area 36 (36c) has the same bilaminate appearance as the rostral part of the field (36r) but has a more uniform appearance and lacks the dense population of satellite glia." (p. 349)
"EC (caudal entorhinal cortex). This field lies immediately behind field EI (Fig. 10). " (p. 344)
"ECL (caudal limiting field of the entorhinal cortex). This field forms the caudal boundary of the entorhinal cortex and was named after Sgonina ('38)." (p. 344)
"EI (the intermediate entorhinal cortex). This field is located at the mid-rostrocaudal levels of the entorhinal cortex (Fig. 10) " (p. 344)

publication.title: The entorhinal cortex of the monkey: I. Cytoarchitectonic organization
publication.abstract:
As an essential preliminary to a series of experimental studies of the afferent and efferent connections of the monkey
entorhinal cortex, we have carried out a detailed analysis of its cytoarchitectonic organization. Primarily on the basis of
features observed in Nissl- and fiber-stained preparations, supplemented with Golgi-stained material and preparations stained for heavy metals by Timm's method and histochemically for acetylcholinesterase, the entorhinal cortex has been divided into seven fields that are named according to their rostrocaudal and mediolateral positions except for one rostrally located field
that is named for the prominent input that it receives from the olfactory bulb. At rostral levels, the entorhinal cortex is marked
by a number of morphological inhomogeneities. The neurons tend to be organized in patches that are surrounded by large,
thick, radially oriented bundles of fibers. At caudal levels, the entorhinal cortex has a more distinctly laminated appearance,
reminiscent of that in the neocortex, and most of the neurons and fiber fascicles are arranged in discrete radial columns. The
cortical region adjoining the entorhinal cortex laterally, which is commonly known as the "perirhinal cortex," is in fact
composed of two separate fields corresponding to areas 35 and 36 of Brodmann. Area 35 occupies the fundus and part of
the lateral aspect of the rhinal sulcus. Area 36 extends from the lateral bank of the rhinal sulcus into the inferior temporal
gyrus, where it borders fields TA and TE rostrally, and field TF of the parahippocampal gyrus caudally. The surface extents
of each of the entorhinal fields have been determined by making "unfolded" two-dimensional maps of the region and
measuring the areas with a computerized digitizing system.
